metadata.titleEn: Urban land use change data in Central Asia (1985-2018)
metadata.description: This dataset includes year-on-year data on urban construction land changes in five countries in Central Asia (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan) from 1985 to 2018. The data has a spatial resolution of 30m and a temporal resolution of one year. It is derived from the Global Artificial Impervious Area (GAIA) change data extracted from Landsat images from 1985 to 2018 (Gong Peng et al.). The researchers evaluated 7 sets of data every 5 years from 1985 to 2015. The average overall accuracy is over 90%, and it is the only urban construction land dataset spanning 30 years.
metadata.instructions:
The data is saved in the "centralAsia_GAIA.tif" file. The pixel values 1-34 corresponds to the years of 2018-1985. A pixel value of 0 means that it is not urban land until 2018.
GeoTIFF files can be read and opened with ArcGIS software and GDAL.

background: Timely, accurate, and frequent information on artiﬁcial impervious areas is critical to understanding the process of urbanization and land use/cover change, as well as of their impacts on the environment and biodiversity. Artiﬁcial impervious areas are mainly man-made structures that are composed of any material that impedes or prevents natural inﬁltration of water into the soil. Since 2005, the advent of freely accessible satellite data made it possible to map urban extent and artiﬁcial impervious areas at the global scale. Despite of many existing eﬀorts in mapping GAIA, annual maps covering a relatively long period of time (i.e., more than 30 years) do not exist.
research objective: The purpose of this research was to develop a 34-year long annual GAIA using the full archive of Landsat data from 1985 to 2018.
challenges: Our previous studies suggest the mapping performance in arid and semi-arid regions is relatively poor due to the highly confusing spectral information between the artiﬁcial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands, resulting in an over commission of artiﬁcial impervious areas in dryland regions.
methods: We developed an automatic mapping procedure on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform to implement the planetary-scale mapping of annual artiﬁcial impervious areas at a 30-m resolution from 1985 to 2018. Therefore, in this research, we divided the whole world into arid areas and non-arid areas according to the global biome map (Olson et al., 2001). To improve the mapping eﬃciency on the GEE, we divided the whole world into 583 geographical grids (3.5º×3.5°), of which 155 grids contain arid biomes. The mapping procedures were implemented in all grids, using the full archive of Landsat time series images.
dataset: Training samples of the impervious area are needed when applying the “Exclusion-Inclusion” algorithm. These sample units (i.e., around 100 per grid) were collected from earlier Landsat images (i.e., near or around the start year of 1985) in reference with higher resolution images in Google Earth; thus they can be spatially and temporally extended to enrich the sample size and applied to subsequent years. High resolution Google Earth images provide more spatial details of artificial impervious areas, while the Landsat time series data help us to locate the urban core in earlier years since most high resolution images became available after 2000. In addition, parts of sample units came from the training sample pool previously generated in our multi-class general-purpose global land cover mapping project (Gong et al., 2013; Li et al., 2017; Zhao et al., 2014).
findings: Our results indicate that the GAIA reached 797,076 km2 in 2018, which is 1.5 times more than that in 1990. A cross-product comparison indicates the GAIA data are the only dataset spanning over 30 years. The temporal trend in GAIA agrees well with other datasets at the local, regional, and global scales.

Definition.Question: What is the 'Exclusion-Inclusion' algorithm in the context of mapping artificial impervious areas?
Definition.Answer: The 'Exclusion-Inclusion' algorithm is a method used for mapping artificial impervious areas by utilizing training samples. These samples are collected from earlier Landsat images and high-resolution images from Google Earth to identify and map impervious areas accurately over time.

Definition.Question: What does 'mapping performance' refer to in the context of arid and semi-arid regions?
Definition.Answer: In this context, 'mapping performance' refers to the accuracy and effectiveness of identifying artificial impervious areas in arid and semi-arid regions. Challenges arise due to confusing spectral information between these areas and surrounding bare lands, leading to potential overestimation of impervious surfaces.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform in planetary-scale mapping?
Definition.Answer: The Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform is significant for planetary-scale mapping as it enables the implementation of an automatic mapping procedure. This procedure divides the world into geographical grids and processes Landsat time series images to map annual artificial impervious areas efficiently at a 30-m resolution from 1985 to 2018.

Comparison.Question: How does the automatic mapping procedure on the Google Earth Engine platform compare to traditional satellite data analysis methods in mapping artificial impervious areas?
Comparison.Answer: The automatic mapping procedure on the Google Earth Engine platform allows for planetary-scale mapping of annual artificial impervious areas using the full archive of Landsat data at a 30-m resolution from 1985 to 2018, offering a more efficient and scalable approach compared to traditional methods. It divides the world into geographical grids and uses an 'Exclusion-Inclusion' algorithm with training samples to improve accuracy, particularly addressing the challenges in arid regions where traditional methods might struggle with confusing spectral information.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection challenges between arid and non-arid regions when mapping artificial impervious areas?
Comparison.Answer: In arid regions, mapping artificial impervious areas faces challenges due to highly confusing spectral information between impervious areas and surrounding bare lands, leading to over commission errors. In contrast, non-arid regions may not face such pronounced spectral confusion, allowing for relatively more straightforward mapping. The research overcomes these challenges by dividing the global mapping tasks into arid and non-arid areas based on a global biome map to improve the accuracy of data collection.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of high-resolution Google Earth images complement Landsat time series data in improving the accuracy of artificial impervious area mapping?
Comparison.Answer: High-resolution Google Earth images provide more spatial details of artificial impervious areas, which complement the Landsat time series data by helping to locate urban cores in earlier years. This combination allows for the spatial and temporal extension of training samples, which enriches the sample size and improves mapping accuracy, particularly in years where high-resolution images were not available.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying factors could be responsible for the challenges in accurately mapping artificial impervious areas in arid and semi-arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The mapping performance in arid and semi-arid regions is relatively poor due to the highly confusing spectral information between the artificial impervious area and the surrounding bare lands, which results in an over commission of artificial impervious areas in dryland regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the division of the world into arid and non-arid areas aid in improving the efficiency of mapping artificial impervious surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: Dividing the world into arid and non-arid areas allows for tailored mapping procedures that consider the specific spectral characteristics of different biomes, thus improving mapping efficiency and accuracy, particularly on the Google Earth Engine platform.

Interpretation.Question: What implications could the temporal trend in the Global Artificial Impervious Area (GAIA) dataset have for understanding urbanization patterns over the past three decades?
Interpretation.Answer: The temporal trend in GAIA, which shows that the area reached 797,076 km2 in 2018, 1.5 times more than in 1990, indicates significant urban expansion. This trend, consistent with other datasets at various scales, provides insight into the acceleration of urbanization processes over the past 30 years.

It helps locate urban cores in earlier years and enriches the sample size, which improves the overall accuracy of the dataset by providing more precise training samples for the 'Exclusion-Inclusion' algorithm.

Causal Consequence.Answer: Mapping artificial impervious areas in arid and semi-arid regions presents challenges due to similar spectral information between impervious areas and surrounding bare lands, leading to over commission errors. This affects the reliability of the dataset, as the performance in these regions is poorer compared to non-arid areas, necessitating tailored methods to enhance dataset accuracy and coverage.

Additionally, training samples from earlier Landsat images, complemented by high-resolution Google Earth images, are used to refine the accuracy of the mapping process.
